audio_caption: The clip begins with an announcement chime, followed by a male speaker stating he is "looking for gold rings" and has "been doing really well this year" working at lakeside parks. He explains his method is to search the edges of the water for rings that slip off while people are swimming, and he is focusing on gold, though he might find coins. He states that if he finds something good he will turn the camera on. The clip ends with a sonar sound.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing excitement about gold rings, describing how he hunts for them when the lake is low. He discusses finding an "18-karat gold ring" with "diamonds set in 14-karat white gold," and then mentions a "chunky gold ring," noting that it's probably the most valuable item he's ever found. He contrasts these finds with the smaller value of silver dimes. Transitioning, he identifies himself as an "AT Max user," and mentions previously using an "AT Pro user," indicating expertise in metal detecting.

The audio clip begins with someone describing a scenario involving metal detectors and finding a gold ring. The speaker, a single male with a conversational tone, mentions "Whites MXT" and details how his friend found a gold ring, adding he "couldn't believe it." He then explains asking his friend to drop the ring to test the VDI, but he "couldn't even hear it."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker recounting his experience with metal detecting, specifically how he "discriminated out those lower numbers." He then explains discovering smaller gold rings that registered lower on the detector, with one being around "40" and a larger one "65". The speaker's tone is conversational, with a hint of excitement. He shifts the conversation to finding gold rings, followed by what seems to be the sound of keys.

The audio begins with a male speaker detailing his new approach to metal detecting, specifically "going after the gold", even to the point of discarding lesser finds. He mentions his previous habits of collecting smaller denomination coins and gold rings, which then transitions to a description of a recent camping trip over Labor Day where he decided to dedicate himself to finding gold. He describes his success in finding gold rings, noting the signal range of different-sized rings. He suggests he had to dig through a lot of pull tabs to find the gold. The speaker then describes hunting near water to find lost rings due to finger shrinkage from the lake water. Finally, the speaker prefaces a metal detecting hunt, admitting to not showing "very many pull tabs," implying that part of the hunt will be sped up. The speech is interrupted by a sound like someone lightly tapping or clinking on a surface.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining how he went into a "slump" after getting "all this stuff" night after night, and describes it as a "700 pull tab slump." He mentions that the listener will see clips from "hunts" and at the end, the "gold ring" he found. He then says "enjoy the hunt." Following that, another male speaker says "Okay, so I'm working this edge".

The clip begins with a male speaker noting a "78 signal," identifying it as potentially a ring, although likely not gold due to the signal strength. He mentions the uncertainty of whether it's silver, planning to test it later, and highlights that they're "next to the edge of the water" and already "finding jewelry." Background sounds consist of ambient water sounds. The clip ends with what sounds like a single, deep cough.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing digging and expressing optimism about a potential gold ring, noting a loud foil sound typically associated with small gold rings. He confirms the presence of foil at the dig site. The speaker then mentions working at the edge, aiming to discover a gold ring. Instead, he excitedly reports finding a Buffalo nickel on the surface. As the clip concludes, ambient water sounds and a brief "okay" is audible.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker excited about getting a "90 signal" and speculates it might be silver before digging it up. After an unsuccessful attempt, the speaker moves on, beginning to hard-dig, finding "1946 silver" and saying that it'll probably bring "500 full cap", going to a gold ring in a week. He then picks up another ring, but is unsure what it is made of and speculates that it's just "some sort of costume jewelry", adding that he'll provide an update if it turns out to be something cool. He continues to hunt in the area, remarking on an area he has worked a few times, hoping to find some fresh drops, before picking up a surface earring, noting its "63 actually" and that it looks like "just bling", ending with, "cool find."

The audio begins with a male speaker excitedly claiming he thinks he's found gold, noting its presence in the plug. He finds it awesome and nice, identifying "14k" on the inside. Explaining he usually only finds pull tabs, he says that this find is why he searches; he comments on the chunkiness of the find, estimating its weight, before expressing the intention to continue searching. This spoken segment is interspersed with "ah" sounds and breathing. In the background, there is a constant wind noise. Abruptly, the clip transitions to dramatic, loud orchestral music.
